hero.headline2: Prove What You Know. Be Recognized.
hero.subtitle1: Don’t let your learning go unnoticed. Discover how Open Badges make your skills visible.

section1.description: Open badges are concerned with proving your soft skills, Assign the cards as you best see fit.
section1.longHelp:
In traditional education, hard skills like lab work, attending lectures or conferences, or hands-on activities are often assessed through grades and exams.

But soft skills—those interpersonal and self-management abilities that shape how we work with others and manage tasks—are just as important, yet rarely evaluated through formal grades.

Open Badges help recognize and validate these soft skills by providing evidence of real experiences, contributions, or behaviors. They give learners a way to prove strengths that aren’t always visible in transcripts, but are crucial in both studies and careers.

section2.longHelp: Open badges must include several required metadata fields such as the badge type, issue date, criteria, and achievement description. This ensures every badge is complete and verifiable.
section2.description: Identify the meta information that is crucial for a viable open badge.

section4.description: As you collect various badges that prove different competences, combining them leads to major Meta badges.

mistake.socialMediaLinks: Social media links are optional and not part of required Open Badge metadata.
mistake.visualDesign: Color themes and visual styling are optional and do not form part of the badge's official metadata.
mistake.badgeAnimation: Animations are visual enhancements and are not valid metadata.
mistake.unencryptedEmail: Your name is considered PII(Personally Identifiable Information) and therefore attaching unecessary PII as metadata is usually avoided.

mistake.excelAnalysis: Excel analysis is a technical skill usually learned in formal education.
mistake.programmingBasics: Programming basics are considered hard skills gained through structured learning.
mistake.timeManagement: Time management is a soft skill related to self-organization and personal habits.
mistake.readingBlueprints: Blueprint reading is a technical hard skill used in construction and engineering.
mistake.teamwork: Teamwork is a soft skill developed through collaboration and group experiences.
mistake.publicSpeaking: Public speaking is a soft skill that helps with communication and confidence.
mistake.labResearch: Conducting lab research is a technical hard skill often taught in scientific education.
mistake.conflictResolution: Conflict resolution is a soft skill essential for navigating interpersonal challenges.
